 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1.        I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity contribution in the ASEAN1 Infrastructure Fund (AIF) of $50,000,000 annually for 3 years, 
commencing from 2011, and ADB’s administration of the AIF. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

2.        ASEAN’s  infrastructure  deficit.  The  estimated  infrastructure  needs  in  the  Asia  and 
Pacific  region  are  large,  about  $750  billion/year  during  2010–2020.  Out  of  this,  the  ASEAN 
region accounts for over $60 billion per year.2 While the ASEAN region has grown rapidly since 
the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis and withstood the impact of the recent global economic crisis, 
this  sustained  growth  has  also  created  huge  pressure  on  the  infrastructure  coverage  of  the 
ASEAN region. Table 1 compares basic infrastructure data for ASEAN, Asia, and other regions.

3.        ASEAN  members  have  been  concerned  about  the  critical  need  to  address  the 
inadequacies of its infrastructure based on a clear recognition that infrastructure development is 
essential  to  the  realization  of  ASEAN’s  goal  of  economic  integration  and  indispensable  to 
establish an ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) by 2015.  
 
4.        As  a  response,  in  2010,  the  ASEAN  leaders  issued  their  Master  Plan  on  ASEAN 
Connectivity (MPAC). This reflected the vision of ASEAN leaders that building an AEC by 2015 
called  for  a  well-connected  ASEAN  that  would  be  more  competitive  and  resilient,  as  it  would 
bring  capital,  peoples,  goods,  and  services  closer.  As  the  priority  projects  of  the  MPAC  will 
require a significant level of financing support, a large pool of financing sources is needed.  
 
5.        ASEAN’s  paradox  on  infrastructure  financing.  The  substantial  resources needed to 
reduce  the  significant  gaps  in  infrastructure  as  shown  above,  and  to  effectively  implement  the 
MPAC,  cannot  be  met  by  the  countries  on  their  own.  At  the  same  time,  both  domestic  and 
international  project  financiers  are  constrained  by  the  market  perception  of  the  high  degree  of 
risk involved in long-tenor infrastructure transactions. While multilateral institutions such as ADB

or  bilateral  institutions  may  meet  a  part  of  the  requirements,  the  resource  requirements  far 
exceed their lending capacity.  
 
6.        More  importantly,  the  region  continues  to  face  a  paradox:  it  has  large  unfunded 
infrastructure  requirements  despite  having  significant  regional  private  savings  and  foreign 
exchange reserves. The ASEAN region currently holds more than $700 billion in reserves.3 The 
solution  to  the  paradox  lies  in  matching  the  resources  with  the  needs  by  (i)  designing funding 
modalities and establishing their track record to translate regional savings into investments; and 
(ii) structuring viable infrastructure projects–including those involving private sector participation 
and public–private partnership (PPP) modality. 
 
7.        Innovative  financing  initiative.    The  proposed  AIF  represents  an  innovative  regional 
cooperation and integration initiative that seeks to address this paradox. Through this initiative, 
and  with  ADB’s  investment,  technical  and  operational  support,  ASEAN’s  investments  will  be 
catalyzed,  representing  an  important  effort  at  south-south  cooperation.4 This  initiative  will  start 
providing effective infrastructure project lending at the country and subregional levels in ASEAN. 
The  AIF  model  thus  holds  the  promise  of  leveraging  future  potential  equity  contributions  and 
cofinancing,  and  subsequently  demonstrating  a  means  of  unlocking  a  portion  of  the  region’s 
own  resources  (such  as  domestic  savings  and  foreign  reserves)  for  its  needs  through  future 
debt issuance.  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

8.        The AIF’s impact will be enhanced access to key infrastructure services within ASEAN. 
The outcome will be greater connectivity within ASEAN, including pooling of resources through 
enhanced  infrastructure,  to  support  the  goals  of  the  AEC.  Specifically,  the  AIF  will  promote 
sustainable  and  inclusive  economic  development  by  financing  the  building  of  high-quality 
physical infrastructure in the region, especially in subregions where development gaps persist. 
While the  overall  financing gap remains  huge,  the  AIF  will  play  a critical  role  as  an  innovative 
source of financing for priority projects, based on a catalytic partnership with ADB. 
 
9. 
Furthermore, during the initial period, the AIF aims to finance the public portion of PPP 
projects; the AIF can also undertake financing the private portion after it develops a good track 
record.  At  the  same  time,  the  AIF  is  financing  infrastructure  hardware  to  help  anchor  and 
complement  the  continued  work  by  ASEAN  and  ADB  to  promote  ―software‖  development  for 
connectivity  -  including  the  cross-border  transport  agreements,  and  customs  reform,  as 
stipulated in the MPAC.    
 
C. 

Outputs 

10.      The AIF will have three main development outputs: (i) additional financing for improved 
infrastructure;  (ii)  enhanced  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  development  through 
PPPs;  and,  (iii)  support  for  MPAC  implementation  for  the  region.  These  outputs  will  lead  to 
increased  financing  for  priority  ASEAN  infrastructure  projects,  maximized  development  impact 
by combining the resources of ASEAN and ADB, and catalyzed private sector investments via 
the  AIF's  support  for  the  public  portions  of  PPP  projects  initially,  and  direct  engagement  in 
private sector projects after a strong track record has been developed. The primary targets are 
outlined below:

Proposed AIF Design 

 
D. 
 
11.      The AIF business model. The AIF's capital structure will comprise equity by the ASEAN 
shareholders and ADB, and debt which is expected to be held by various investors including the 
ASEAN  central  banks.  The  AIF  will  lend  for  long-tenor  sovereign  or  sovereign  guaranteed 
infrastructure  projects,  including  public  portions  of  PPP  projects,  beginning  in  2012.  Every 
sovereign or sovereign-guaranteed project financed by the AIF will also be cofinanced by ADB. 
The loan proceeds will be provided through ADB as the lender of record for the AIF.   
 
12.      The AIF will begin its operations with the equity contributions provided by  nine ASEAN 
shareholders  and  ADB.    This  is  expected  to  be  augmented  by  hybrid  capital,6 which  is  issued 
after  about  4-5  years  of  operations.  The  ASEAN  shareholders  will  participate  directly  by 
providing  equity  capital.  The  source  of  equity  contributions  may  vary  across  the  countries, 
subject to country-specific circumstances. Once the AIF establishes a track record (after about 5 
years  of  operations),  it  will  issue  debt.  Debt  issuance  is  an  important  feature  of  the  AIF’s 
business model—since it is designed to target the use of the region’s foreign exchange reserves 
(while  maintaining  their  reserve  eligibility)  based  on  high  investment  grade  credit  rating  and 
sufficient liquidity.7 ADB has sought the advice of rating advisory services to guide the process 
of obtaining a credit rating, which would be required when the AIF issues debt. Specifically, for 
central  banks,  the  purchase  is  expected  eventually  to  attain  eligibility  as  foreign  exchange 
reserves  as  the  AIF  securities  issued  in  freely  usable  foreign  currency  attains  a  clear  track 
record  and  sufficient  lending  volume  (important  for  liquidity  and/or  marketability  of  the  AIF 
bonds).8 Additional debt investments are also possible through pension funds, sovereign wealth

6  Hybrid capital refers to a financial instrument that has some characteristics of both debt and shareholder's equity. A

included  as  eligible  Tier-I  capital  in  the  Basel-III  framework  depending  on  the  design  characteristic  of  the 
instrument.  Like the regulators, rating agencies view hybrid as a positive factor and are comfortable with providing 
equity credit.  

7   High investment grade long-term credit rating is considered as ―A/A2‖ to ―AA/Aa2‖.   
8  The  International  Monetary  Fund’s  (IMF)  International  Reserves  and  Foreign  Currency  Liquidity-Guidelines  has 
provided guidance on how national authorities might apply the reserve guidelines to the determination of whether 
particular assets should be treated  as international reserves. IMF has clarified that: (i) the requirement for reserve 
assets to be external means that they should be claims on non-residents rather than residents;  (ii) to be ―readily 
available‖ the assets should be denominated in a convertible or freely usable foreign currency and should also be 
highly  liquid;  and  (iii)  it  is  desirable  that  reserve  assets  be  of  ―high‖ credit  quality  (investment  grade  and  above).

13.      Equity  structure.  The AIF will be established with a total equity contribution of $485.2 
million.  Nine  ASEAN  members  have  agreed  to  contribute  $335.2  million  in  equity,  while  ADB 
has been requested to provide $150 million.9 The equity contributions will be divided into three 
annual  tranches.    In  addition,  about  $162  million  will  later  be  added  from  hybrid  capital, 
augmenting the equity resources. Table 3 presents the equity contribution for the AIF.10 

 
14.      Debt.  The  AIF  plans  to  issue  debt  around  5  years  after  it  commences  operations.  To 
ensure  that  the  AIF  is  an  effective  financial  intermediary,  the  AIF  should  ensure  its  ability  to 
access  capital  markets  at  terms  suitable  for  development  purposes.  For  this,  the  stand-alone 
financial  strength  of  an  entity  is  extremely  important.  Such  financial  strength,  which  will  be 
assessed  by  rating  agencies,  will  be  based  on  (i)  strong  shareholder  support;  (ii)  prudent 
financial policies (including adequacy of capital, credit quality of the loan portfolio, and liquidity 
management);  and  (iii)  ADB’s  operational  experience  (including  project  lending,  cofinancing,  
corporate governance and institutionalization of the new entity). Most importantly, with ADB as 
cofinancier and lender of record, the AIF loans will derive comfort from cross-default with ADB 
loans.  These  considerations  and  an  initial  leverage  target  based  on  a  good  track  record  are 
expected to enable the AIF to achieve in due course a high, investment-grade rating from major 
international rating agencies. 

                                                                                                                                                       
ADB  and  the  AIF  will continue  to  monitor any  major  changes  in  the  investment  guidelines  of  the  ASEAN  central 
banks.  

9   ASEAN members recognize the long-term requirements for the AIF to fulfill its development objectives. However, 
the  shareholders  also  agreed  that  there  should  be  a  comprehensive  review  of  the  AIF  operations  around  2014, 
prior  to  hybrid  capital  and  bond  issuance  and  before  commencement  of  any  nonsovereign  operations.  Another 
such  review  is  anticipated  in  2016,  at  which  time  options  on  changes  to  the  capital  structure  of  the  AIF  will  be 
considered, in light of the performance of the AIF and the equity investment climate at that time.

15.      Pricing and return. The development-oriented approach of the AIF with loans based on 
cost-pass-through pricing policy  will limit  the AIF’s risk. Delegation of the AIF administration to 
ADB without incurring the AIF staffing costs will help minimize the AIF’s costs for its borrowers. 
It would be possible for the AIF to increase its returns to make itself more attractive to private 
investors,  but  this  would  imply  a  sharp  increase  in  its  pricing.  Table  4 summarizes  the  overall 
features.  
 
16.      Current  project  pipeline.  ADB  has  prepared  a  preliminary  project  pipeline  for  2012–
2013,  based  on  initial  country  consultations.  The  pipeline  emphasizes  project  diversification 
through 3-year rolling exposure limits for individual countries, sectors, and projects to strengthen 
the  AIF’s  portfolio  credit  quality.  Accordingly,  the  following  exposure  limits  have  been 
considered  for  business  planning:  (i) 30%  per  country,  (ii)  40%  per  sector,  and  (iii)  a  single-
project limit of $75 million. The preliminary list of projects requires confirmation from borrowing 
governments.  The  AIF  board  will  actively  review  and  approve  the  project  pipeline  prior  to  the 
start  of  the  AIF’s  operational  lending  program.  Further  adjustments  will  be  needed  to  fully 
adhere to the exposure limits as described above. 
 
17.      Projects will be from the larger pipeline of potential requirements identified by individual 
ASEAN  members  jointly  with  ADB  during  regular  country  partnership  strategy  process  and 
consultations  or  as  part  of  regional  cooperation  initiatives  such  as  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion  program,  the  Brunei-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area 
program or the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle program. ADB may examine any 
viable  sovereign  or  sovereign-guaranteed  project  proposal  for  the  AIF  financing  based  on  the 
principles endorsed by participating ASEAN members.11 

                                                
11 In addition, the AIF will support the implementation of the MPAC, which has identified a number of key projects to 

facilitate physical and policy connectivity among the member countries.

18.      Nonsovereign  projects. While the AIF will engage only in sovereign operations during 
its initial operations, once a strong track record has been developed, the AIF board may decide 
to  expand  to  nonsovereign  (private)  operations.    This  phased  approach  is  considered  to  be  a 
prudent  way  to  ensure  that  the  AIF  receives  a  high  investment-grade  rating,  as  nonsovereign 
operations  without  full  sovereign  guarantees  are  considered  to  be  inherently  more  risky  than 
sovereign operations.   
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

19.      ADB's  role. The participating ASEAN members have requested ADB to provide the full 
range  of  services  relating  to  project  sourcing,  design,  execution,  implementation,  and 
evaluation,  as well  as the management  of  the AIF funds.12 ADB  has  been requested to  act  as 
the  lender  of  record  for  all  AIF  loans  to  maximize  benefits  associated  with  processing  and 
administration by ADB. ADB will provide these services to the AIF under an express delegation 
of powers from and other terms and conditions agreed with the  AIF board. The mobilization of 
resources from within ASEAN will supplement and complement the resource pool of ADB, while 
tapping  ADB’s  experience  in  infrastructure  development.  This  model  of  pooling  resources, 
knowledge,  and  experience  will  significantly  reduce  transaction  cost  and  provide  a  significant 
comfort level to the credit rating agencies 
 
20.      For ASEAN, ADB will submit a project pipeline and a detailed annual report on the AIF, 
including financial statements and relevant financial and operational projections, for discussion 
at the AIF board meetings.13 The specific details of the AIF’s governance structure are provided 
below (paras. 23-24).14 ADB's accountability to its Board of Directors will be through the regular 
project approval and reporting processes. 

                                                
12  The administration of the AIF will be undertaken by an interdepartmental working group. 
13 The  AIF  legal  documents  will  clearly state  the  specific  functions  and  scope  (including  information  sharing, 
indemnification of ADB as administrator, except in case of gross negligence) of each role that ADB will undertake. 
Detailed discussions of this delegation of power have been held among the ASEAN shareholders and ADB. 

14 In addition, it should be noted that all ASEAN members are represented on the ADB Board, which will facilitate the 

communication among ADB and the ASEAN members.

A. 

Economic and Financial 

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 

21.      Demand  assessment.  Total  infrastructure  investment  requirements  in  ASEAN  are 
formidable,  at  over  $60  billion  per  year  for  the  next  10  years.  On  average,  the  public  sector 
(national and subnational governments, and state-owned enterprises) should meet about 35%–
40% of these requirements. Multilateral and bilateral institutions may contribute about 10-12%, 
and the rest should be mobilized from the private sector, including national and foreign financial 
institutions.  At  present,  the  public  sector  is  unable  to  exceed  about  20%  because  of  fiscal 
constraints, and the private sector also invests only the same amount or less in the absence of 
robust  risk-sharing  arrangements.  As  a  result,  a  solid  pipeline  of  projects  will  need  to  be 
financed by new mechanisms such as the AIF.  
 
22.      Financial assessment. The retained earnings operating under a targeted debt-to-equity 
ratio of 1.5:1 will result in  an increase of the value of equity; assuming each share has a face 
value  of  $10,000,  the  book  value  of  these  equity  shares  is  projected  to  become  $16,642  by 
2026 at a compounded annual growth rate of 3.7%.15 The AIF will begin issuing long-term debt 
in around 2016 with a moving 5-year average funding plan of about $275 million to be raised to 
an average of $450 million to $500 million from 2021.16 The speed of leverage is gradual with 
an incremental increase in the debt–equity ratio.  
 
B. 

Governance 

23.      Board  of  Directors. The AIF’s board of directors is the ultimate decision making body. 
Its main functions include the consideration and approval of the selection criteria for projects to 
be financed by the AIF and a rolling 3-year project pipeline that will be a part of the overall AIF 
annual  report,  in  a  form  of  project  concept  paper,  to  be  prepared  by  ADB. 17 Each  of  the 
shareholders  will  be  represented  on  the  AIF  board.  It  will  meet  at  least  once  a  year  and  from 
time to time, as appropriate. All decisions taken at a duly constituted Board meeting, except with 
respect to the fundamental  issues18 shall  be  decided by  the  shareholders who  hold more  than 
50% of the voting power in the AIF and at least 50% of the number of shareholders.  
 
24.      AIF  domicile.  As  agreed  among  the  participating  ASEAN  members,  the  AIF  will  be 
domiciled  in  Malaysia  as  a  limited  liability  company,  and  thus  its  operations  will  be  consistent 
with Malaysia's legal framework. The Government of Malaysia has indicated that it will seek to 
enact  special  legislation  for  the  AIF’s  benefit  generally,  including  exemption  of  the  AIF  from 
foreign exchange controls and from all Malaysian taxation.

C. 

Poverty and Social Impacts 

25.      Major poverty and social impacts of the AIF will include (i) promotion of economic growth 
and  employment  generation;  (ii)  expansion  of  basic  infrastructure,  especially  for  the  poor;  and 
(iii)  facilitation  of  trade  and  investments  through  more  efficient  infrastructure.    It  will  help  to 
provide people with greater access to  energy, power, clean water and sanitation, and improve 
their  mobility  through  better forms  of transportation.  In  addition,  the  AIF can  also  support rural 
development and cross-border projects.   
 
D. 

Safeguards 

26.      ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) will apply to all AIF projects.   
 
E. 

Investment Limitations 

27.      ADB’s  proposed  equity  contribution  of  $150  million  in  aggregate  will  exceed  the  single 
exposure  limit  of  $75 million  and  25%  of  the  total  equity.19 The proposed amount  is,  however, 
considered  to  be  appropriate  given  the  commitments  of  the  ASEAN  shareholders  and  the 
important role that the AIF will play in financing of infrastructure development in ASEAN. 
 
F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures

presented below. The development impact and innovative nature of this project are deemed to 
outweigh the risks.

Mitigating Measures 

The country commitment and payment schedule was confirmed by ASEAN shareholders in 
July 2011. The AIF will not start operations unless and until at least 80% of the first tranche

A high, investment-grade rating is preferred to ensure that the central banks can invest their 
foreign reserves. If the AIF does not attain such a rating, it will need to adjust its  projected 
lending  rate,  lending  volume,  and  return  on  equity.  However,  credit  rating  agencies  and 
advisors have indicated that the following are key mitigating factors:  
(i)  Shareholders’  Support:  The  AIF  is  owned  by  ASEAN  sovereigns  and  ADB  and  will 
lend to the same ASEAN sovereigns on infrastructure – thus, a perception of default is 
minimized.  The AIF board, representing the ASEAN sovereigns and ADB, will provide 
additional assurance of strong ownership support. Malaysia will issue special legislation 
for the AIF’s benefit generally. 

(ii)  Sovereign Borrowers’ and ADB’s Role: ADB will provide a cross-default arrangement 
through  the  complementary  financing  scheme;  ADB  will  cofinance,  process,  and 
implement  all  AIF  projects;  ADB  will  administer  the  AIF on  relevant  aspects, including 
financial management. A set of exposure limits by sector and country and per project is 
in place to ensure the diversification of the project portfolio.  

(iii)  Region’s  History  and  Dynamics:  While  the  individual  sovereign  ratings  tend  to  be 
low,  collectively  the  region  has  a  good  history  of  low  defaults.  ASEAN  has  been  an 
established group for many years and interacts with partner countries outside ASEAN 
(e.g.,  the  +3  process).  Credit  rating  agencies  have  recognized  this  by  introducing  a

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

29.      All AIF shareholders have agreed that  all projects financed by the AIF  shall conform to 
all  of  ADB's  mandatory  policies  on  anticorruption,  procurement,  consulting  services, 
disbursement,  accountability  mechanism,  and others  as  appropriate.  In addition,  each ASEAN 
shareholder  has  agreed to appoint  ADB  to  administer  the  AIF,  including the management  and 
disbursement  of  the  AIF  funds  according  to  agreed  terms  and  conditions.  Accordingly,  it  is 
considered that a project administration manual would not be needed.  
 
30.      All the AIF shareholders have agreed that the AIF will commence operations only after at 
least 80% of the first tranche equity contributions have been contributed.
